Article Identification of stable and selective nickel alloy catalyst for acceptorless dehydrogenation of ethane Guomin Li a b c 1 Teng Li a 1 Bin Wang a Yong Ding b Xinjiang Cui a * Feng Shi a * a State Key Laboratory of Low Carbon Catalysis and Carbon Dioxide Utilization, State Key Laboratory for Oxo Synthesis and Selective Oxidation, Lanzhou Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Lanzhou 730000, Gansu, China State Key Laboratory of Low Carbon Catalysis and Carbon Dioxide Utilization State Key Laboratory for Oxo Synthesis and Selective Oxidation Lanzhou Institute of Chemical Physics Chinese Academy of Sciences Lanzhou Gansu 730000 China State Key Laboratory of Low Carbon Catalysis and Carbon Dioxide Utilization, State Key Laboratory for Oxo Synthesis and Selective Oxidation, Lanzhou Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Lanzhou 730000, Gansu, China b State Key Laboratory of Applied Organic Chemistry, Key Laboratory of Advanced Catalysis of Gansu Province, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Lanzhou University, Lanzhou 730000, Gansu, China State Key Laboratory of Applied Organic Chemistry Key Laboratory of Advanced Catalysis of Gansu Province College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Lanzhou University Lanzhou Gansu 730000 China State Key Laboratory of Applied Organic Chemistry, Key Laboratory of Advanced Catalysis of Gansu Province, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Lanzhou University, Lanzhou 730000, Gansu, China c University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China University of Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100049 China University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China * Corresponding author. 1 Contributed equally to this work. Modifying the electronic density of states and the synergistic effect of the active centers by introducing a second metal present an efficient strategy to tune physi/chemi-sorption, probably lead to improving catalytic performances. Herein, bimetallic Ni3Mo/Al2O3 catalyst was demonstrated and exhibited over 5 times more active than Pt/Al2O3 toward the ethane dehydrogenation (EDH) as well as 2–10 times activity enhancement compared with their monometallic Ni and Mo counterparts and other Ni-based bimetallic nanoparticles. Kinetic studies revealed that the activation energy over Ni3Mo/Al2O3 (111 kJ mol–1) was much lower than that of Ni (157 kJ mol–1) and Mo (171 kJ·mol–1). DFT calculations showed ethane was adsorbed on the Ni or Mo surface in a more parallel configuration, whereas over Ni3Mo it adopted an inclined configuration. This change promoted ethane adsorption and pre-activation of the C–H bond, thereby benefiting the ethane dehydrogenation process on the Ni3Mo surface. Graphical Abstract The modification of electronic density of states of Ni and Mo in Ni3Mo alloy leaded to the adsorption of ethane into an inclined configuration, which was more conducive for ethane dehydrogenation. Keywords Acceptorless dehydrogenation Bimetallic nanoparticle Catalyst Olefin Mechanism 1 Introduction Unsaturated light olefins (ethylene and propylene), which are raw chemical material, have been extensively used as building blocks for the production of a widespread array of products, including fibers, plastics, surfactants, chemical intermediates and other fine chemicals [ 1,2 ]. Traditionally, the production of the light olefins is through the stream cracking and fluid catalytic cracking of naphtha or gas oil. In addition, the methanol-to-olefins (MTO) reaction, which is well known as a nonpetroleum strategy using coal and natural gas resources, can also produce these basic chemicals [ 3 ]. With the recent boom of shale gas exploration across the world, predominantly methane, ethane and propane, the direct conversion of light alkanes to olefins provides a promising alternative route. The oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) of light alkanes has been widely investigated because higher olefin yield could be obtained under reduced temperature [ 4–8 ]. However, the ODH process operated under oxidizing atmosphere also brings disadvantages such as complete loss of produced hydrogen as water, over-oxidation with undesirable products and safety issue. The catalytic alkane dehydrogenation without oxidants over supported catalysts has received increasing attention as a means for producing light olefins and hydrogen [ 9–13 ]. Platinum based materials typically supported on Al2O3 or aluminates, have showing outperform catalytic performance in direct dehydrogenation for light alkanes, achieving good catalytic activity and stability [ 14–16 ]. However, the high price and scarcity of Pt metal seriously drive to develop noble metal free catalyst on the dehydrogenation for light alkanes. Non-noble chromium oxide displays activity and selectivity in alkane dehydrogenation reactions [ 17,18 ], yet suffering from the hazardous nature of Cr species. Besides the Cr-based catalyst, other earth-abundant monometallic metals/oxides (Fe [ 19,20 ], Co [ 21,22 ], Ni [ 23,24 ], Zn [ 25,26 ], Ga [ 27–29 ], Mo [ 30,31 ], V [ 32 ] and In [ 33 ]) have been also applied in direct dehydrogenation of light alkanes, but only low activities and selectivities achieved. As such, the design of low-cost and environmentally friendly catalysts is of great importance from the perspective of industrial applications. Compared with their monometallic counterparts, bimetallic nanoparticles (NPs) could offer enhanced physical and chemical properties by the addition of a secondary metallic element [ 34–38 ]. Because of the changes in the electronic density of states and the synergistic effect between bimetallic species, the substrate adsorption and product desorption on the catalyst surface could be tuned, probably affording improved catalytic performances. Specially, fascinating catalytic properties have attracted extensive research interests in the wide range of redox reactions [ 39–44 ], especially in the dehydrogenation reactions [ 45,46 ]. At present, the research on bimetallic catalysts for light alkane dehydrogenation was still mainly focused on optimizing Pt based catalysts [ 47–49 ], and the application of transition metal bimetallic catalysts in alkane dehydrogenation was gradually emerging. Laursen et al. [ 46 ] reported the effect of NiGa bimetallic loading and proportion on surface activity, while Zhang et al. [ 50 ] investigated the synergistic effect of bimetallic on propane dehydrogenation activity by introducing a second metal to regulate the electronic structure of Ni. From this, it could be seen that there are many different insights into the working principle of bimetallic catalysts. Therefore, fundamental understanding of the synergistic structures of active sites thus becomes important for the development of bimetallic catalysts for light alkanes dehydrogenation to achieve superior catalytic performances compared to the monometallic ones. In this work, Ni-M bimetallic NPs with varying the second metal and Ni:M ratios immobilized on commercially aluminum oxide was presented. The resulting Ni3Mo/Al2O3 nanoalloys displayed over 5 times more active than Pt/Al2O3 toward the dehydrogenation of ethane and 2–10 times improved catalytic activity compared with their monometallic counterparts and other bimetallic NPs. The experimental results showed that the activation energy over Ni3Mo/Al2O3 was much lower than that of Ni and Mo. Moreover, DFT calculations revealed that adsorption geometry was changed from parallel configuration on the Ni or Mo to inclined one on Ni3Mo, promoting the ethane adsorption and ethane dehydrogenation. These findings revealed that it is the NiMo interaction in Ni3Mo alloy that changes the adsorption state of alkanes, resulting in excellent ethane dehydrogenation performance. This provided a new insight into the mechanism of synergistic effects. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation All catalysts were prepared via incipient impregnation method. The preparation of Ni3Mo/Al2O3 was exemplified: Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (96.2 mg) and (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O (19.5 mg) were dissolved in water (2.0 mL), and then activated alumina (2.0 g) was added as support. After the impregnation was completed, the impregnated sample was dried at 100 °C for 12 h and then calcinated in a muffle furnace under air atmosphere at a temperature of 700 °C for 3 h. Afterwards, 0.5 g precatalysts was put into a fixed bed reaction tube and reduced with 10% H2/Ar for 2 h at 600 °C which was demonstrated as Ni3Mo/Al2O3 catalyst. It can be adjusted as needed to obtain Ni x Mo/Al2O3 catalysts with different metal ratios, loading capacities, and calcination temperatures. Using the same method, the Ni3M/Al2O3 catalysts with different bimetallics were prepared by replacing Mo salts with equimolar amounts of other metal salts, and the Pt/Al2O3 catalyst was prepared replacing transition metal salts with anhydrous chloroplatinic acid (42 mg). 2.2 Catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were collected on a STADIP automated transmission diffractometer (STOE). The TEM images and high-angle annular darkfield scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) images were obtained on a JEOL JEM-2100F microscope instrument operated with accelerating voltage of 300 kV. The contents of various metal elements in the catalysts were measured by inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES), using an Iris advantage Thermo Jarrel Ash device. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was obtained by a VG ES-CALAB 210 instrument equipped with a 5 keV Ar ion gun. In order to obtain the fresh surface state of the active center, the samples were etched with Ar ion at a low energy state of 2000 eV for 40 s and then analyzed by XPS again. The X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) spectra were performed at the Beijing Synchrotron Radiation Facility (1W1B BSRF) in the Institute of High Energy Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences with a storage ring energy of 2.5 GeV and a beam current between 150 and 250 mA. The Ni/Mo edge absorbance of powder catalysts was measured in transmission geometry at room temperature. EXAFS data analysis was carried out using iffeffit analysis programs (http://cars9.uchicago.edu/ifeffit/). Temperature programmed reduction by H2 (H2-TPR) was conducted on the chemical adsorption analyzer (TP-5080d-tianjin Xianquan industry and Trade Co., Ltd.). The catalyst was pretreated at 400 °C for 1 h with flowing He, and then cooled to room temperature. Subsequently, the sample was flushed by 5% H2/N2 (40 mL min–1), and heated it to 900 °C (10 °C min–1), and maintained for 20 min. The active metal surface area of the catalyst was determined by CO-TPD using this instrument. The catalyst was reduced in situ and then cooled to room temperature under CO (20 mL min–1) flowing. After maintain at room temperature for 30 min, the sample was flushed by Ar (40 mL min–1) until it stabilized, and then it was heated to 600 °C (20 °C min–1) under Ar flowing, and maintained for 10 min [ 51 ]. A stoichiometric Ni/CO ratio of 1 (mol/mol) was assumed [ 52 ] and calculated the active specific surface area of the catalyst using the following formula. (1) A N i = V 0 N a A m 22.4 × 10 7 m c a t (2) D N i = 58.7 V 0 22.4 × 10 3 m c a t w t where A Ni is the active specific surface area, m2 g–1; V 0 is the adsorption capacity of CO in standard state, ml; A m is the cross-sectional area of Ni atoms, 6.5 × 10–16 cm2; N a is the Avogadro constant, 6.02 × 1023; m cat is the mass of the catalyst, g; D Ni is the dispersion of Ni, %; wt is the loading amount of Ni in the catalyst, %. In situ FTIR was collected on the experimental device built in our institute. After in situ reduction of the catalyst in the sample cell, 30% ethane (30 mL min–1, N2 as equilibrium gas) was introduced at 550 °C and maintained for 30 min. Subsequently, flushed with N2 for 20 min (21 mL min–1). The infrared spectrum was continuously collected from the time when ethane was introduced to the time when purging was completed. The temperature programmed surface reaction of ethane (C2H6-TPSR) experiments was performed on a fixed bed reactor equipped with an on-line mass spectrometer (Shanghai Pro-tech Limited Company). Typically, 0.5 g of the sample was placed in a fixed bed reactor and reduced in situ with 10% H2/Ar flow at 600 °C for 2 h to activate and achieve optimal catalytic state. Subsequently, the gas was switched to a mixed reaction gas state (H2:C2H6:Ar = 2:5:18, 25 mL min–1), and the trend of products composition with temperature was detected at 300 to 650 °C. The signals of H2 (m/z = 2), C2H6 (m/z = 30), C2H4 (m/z = 24) were monitored during the experiment. 2.3 Catalyst performance evaluation 0.5 g catalyst (20–40 mesh) was placed in a stainless-steel reaction tube with an inner diameter of 8 mm, and H2/Ar mixture (10% H2, 20 mL min–1) was introduced at the same time. The catalyst was heated to 600 °C for 2 h at a heating rate of 20 °C min–1. Then the reaction temperature was tuned to the required temperature, and ethane was fed into the reaction tube (H2:C2H6:Ar = 2:5:18). Shimadzu GC-2014c was used for online sampling and analyzing of raw materials and products. The conversion of ethane and the selectivity of ethylene were calculated by relative correction factor. The calculation formula was: (3) C = ( 1 - f c 2 H 6 × A c 2 H 6 % ∑ i f i × A i % ) × 100 % (4) S i = f i × A i % ∑ i f i × A i % × 100 % Among them, C was the conversion of ethane and Si was the selectivity of the product (i). A i% was the area percentage of the corresponding products (i) at the outlet end of the fixed bed, fi was the corresponding correction factor. The apparent activation energy for C2H6 conversion over catalysts was measured in the kinetic region and it was calculated according to the following equation: (5) 1n rc 2H4 = - E a R T + 1n A 0 where r C2H4 is the ethylene synthesis rate (mol g−1 min−1), E a is the activation energy for EDH, A 0 is the pre-exponential factor, R is the ideal gas constant, and T is the reaction temperature. 2.4 Computational methods All calculations were performed via spin-polarized density functional theory implemented in VASP [ 53–55 ]. GGA-PBE was adopted to calculate the exchange and correlation energies of electrons [ 56,57 ]. Considering the convergence criterions for energy and force per atom should be less than 10–5 eV and 0.01 eV Å–1, Methfessel-Paxton scheme was used. The cut-off energy was set to be 400 eV and the vacuum layer between the periodically repeated slabs was set as 15 Å. For (4 × 4) Ni(111), (4 × 4) Mo(110) and (2 × 2) Ni3Mo(100) (Ni3Mo was in Pmmn space group), five atomic layers were built and the bottom two layers were fixed. K-point sampling in Brillouin zone was in Monkhorst-Pack method with 3 × 3 × 1 for Ni(111) and Mo(110), 4 × 5 × 1 for Ni3Mo(100). The adsorption energy (E ads) of adsorbate (X) is obtained from the equation E ads = E X/slab − E slab – E X, where E X/slab is the total energy of the slab with adsorbate (after adsorption), E slab is the total energy of the clean adsorbent slab, E X is the total energy of the free adsorbate (X); and therefore, the more negative E ads, the higher (or stronger) the interactions between the adsorbates and surface; and the opposite number of E ads is regarded as the desorption energy E des. For reactions, the climbing-image nudged elastic band (CI-NEB) method [ 58,59 ] was adopted to search the transition states (TS) and the vibrational frequency analysis was also processed to verify the authentic transition state with only one imaginary frequency. The reaction barrier (E a) is defined as E a = E TS − E IS and the reaction energy (E r) is defined as E r = E FS − E IS, where E IS, E FS and E TS are the total energies of the initial, final and transition states, respectively. Zero-point energy (ZPE) correction was included in all energies. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physicochemical properties of catalysts The XRD patterns of the Ni3Mo/Al2O3 and other samples were presented in Fig. S1, from which no diffraction peaks of crystallized particles were observed because of the low loading and high dispersion of Ni and M. After the reaction, Ni3Mo/Al2O3 still only had diffraction peaks of Al2O3, indicating that the active metal remained highly dispersed during the reaction. The TEM image in Fig. 1(a) clearly displayed that NiMo alloys were uniformly dispersed on the surface of Al2O3 support. The diameter of the NiMo alloys of Ni3Mo/Al2O3 was in the range of 3–5 nm. As indicated by the particle lattice in the inset of Fig. 1(b), the formation of the lattice facet of Ni3Mo(100) with the well-defined lattice spacing of 2.26 Å was displayed. The large number of exposed Ni3Mo(100) crystal planes in more TEM images (Fig. S2) implied that the Ni3Mo(100) crystal plane was the dominant crystal plane of Ni3Mo alloy. Additionally, the high-angle annular dark field (HAADF)-STEM imaging, energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) line scanning and EDX mapping was applied to further confirm the formation of NiMo bimetallic NPs. As shown in Figs. 1(g)–(i), the HAADF-STEM and EDX mapping of Ni3Mo/Al2O3 indicated that Ni and Mo species were homogeneously dispersed on the surface of support. The overall Mo to Ni ratio was determined to be 1:3 based on ICP-AES measurements (Table S1). As a comparison, we performed the characterizations over Ni/Al2O3, Mo/Al2O3 and the used Ni3Mo/Al2O3 catalysts where the Ni and Mo metals were also highly dispersed on the surface of Al2O3 support (Figs. 1(c)–(f) and Fig. S3). Obviously, no aggregated metal NPs were observed over used Ni3Mo/Al2O3 catalyst, indicating the stable nature of Ni3Mo alloy structure (Fig. S4). Other bimetallic catalysts, such as Ni3Ga, Ni3In and Ni3Cu on the Al2O3 support, were selected to characterize and similar Ni3M alloy NPs were formed under the same conditions and highly dispersed on the surface of Al2O3 support (Fig. S5), which was consistent with XRD analysis. The XANES spectra associated with the Ni K-edge and Mo K-edge of the Ni3Mo/Al2O3 catalysts were showed in Figs. 2(a) and (b) , respectively. The K-edge XANES spectra of Ni and Mo exhibited the absorption edges of all samples were higher than those of pure metal reference samples, because the catalyst was easily oxidized after reduction. Although the sample was prone to oxidation, the interaction between Ni and Mo can still be observed where the absorption edge of Ni and Mo of the used Ni3Mo/Al2O3 were closer to pure metal absorption edge, indicating the formation of Ni-Mo NPs in Ni3Mo/Al2O3 during the PDH reaction. While the Ni absorption edge of fresh Ni3Mo/Al2O3 was slightly shifted to the lower energy direction compared to Ni/Al2O3 (Fig. 2(a)) and the Mo absorption edge of fresh Ni3Mo/Al2O3 was slightly shifted towards the higher energy direction compared to Mo/Al2O3 (Fig. 2(b)) which could be attributed to the formation of alloyed Ni-Mo phase and the electron transferred from Mo to Ni. Based on the R-space analysis of the Fourier transform (FT) EXAFS spectrum in Figs. 2(c) and (d), Ni3Mo/Al2O3 after use obviously exhibited the presence of Ni-Mo peak at ~2.56 Å [ 60 ], further confirming the formation of NiMo alloys in Ni3Mo/Al2O3 during the reaction. Due to the easy oxidization of metallic Ni species, the XPS combined with argon ion etching was used to characterize the detailed elemental composition and surface chemical state of Ni3Mo/Al2O3. After etching the sample with argon ion at a low energy state of 2000 eV for 40 s, the XPS spectrum of the etched sample showed increased reduced species signals (Figs. 2(e) and 2(f) and Fig. S6). The Ni 2p spectra of Ni3Mo/Al2O3 demonstrated that the binding energies (BEs) at 852.98 and 855.92 eV were ascribed to Ni 2p 3/2 of Ni0 and Ni2+ [ 61,62 ], respectively. The Mo 3d peaks of Ni3Mo/Al2O3 and Mo/Al2O3 were displayed in Fig. 2(f) and the BE at 228.46 eV was ascribed to Mo 3d 5/2 of Mo0 [ 61,62 ]. Compared with that of the Mo/Al2O3, the Mo 3d BE of the Ni3Mo/Al2O3 catalyst showed a shift to higher BEs of approximately 0.35 eV, suggesting that the formation of Ni-Mo NPs affected the electronic properties. In addition, the Ni 2p spectrum of the Ni3Mo NPs was slightly shifted toward lower BE (0.14 eV), implying efficient electronic coupling between Ni and Mo. The XPS analysis confirmed the interatomic charge polarization appears in the Ni3Mo NPs and the electron transfer from Mo to Ni [ 60,63,64 ], leading to a negative charge of the Ni species, which was consistent with the XANES results. The H2-TPR experiments were conducted to study redox behavior of various NiM bimetallic catalysts (Fig. S7). In the 5% H2/N2 reducing atmosphere, both Ni/Al2O3 and Mo/Al2O3 were fully reduced at 900 °C while Ni3Mo/Al2O3 exhibited H2 consumption peak of at lower temperature of 837.5 °C, which can be ascribed to the formation of Ni3Mo alloyed NPs. Meanwhile, other proportions of NiMo catalysts displayed higher reduction temperature than Ni3Mo/Al2O3, indicating that the introduction of the Ni3Mo bimetallic NPs could significantly reduce the reduction temperature compared with the mono-metal catalysts and the Ni/Mo ratio of 3 presented the best reduction ability. The quantitative analysis of H2-TPR combined with ICP results showed that the reduction degree of Ni3Mo/Al2O3 was 87.5%, indicating that most active metals could be reduced at lower temperatures, further proving the formation of Ni3Mo alloy. The results of CO-TPD (Fig. S8) showed that the dispersion of Ni in Ni3Mo/Al2O3 was 27.4%, which was higher than 14.0% of Ni/Al2O3, indicating that Ni3Mo/Al2O3 has a higher specific surface area for activity (0.148 m2 g–1) 3.2 NiM/Al2O3 for ethane dehydrogenation To test the catalytic performance of the above catalyst on EDH, we compared the initial activities of the catalysts with fixed molar ratio of Ni to various second metals (3:1) and also fixed content of Ni (0.165 mmol g–1) (Table S2). The conversion and selectivity for EDH for Ni based bimetallic catalysts determined with 20% C2H6, 8% H2 with balanced Ar at 600 °C after prereduction at 600 °C. As shown in Fig. 3(a) , the initial conversions of ethane were in the range of 2% to 3.5% and increased slightly in the order of Cu, Sn, Fe, In, Co, Ga and Zn when they were introduced as the second metal. For all catalysts, the selectivity to ethylene was in the range of 87%–96% with minor amounts of methane. Surprisingly, the addition of Mo improved catalytic activity significantly with the initial ethane conversion up to 11%, which was 3–5 times higher than that by other bimetallic catalysts. Meanwhile, the selectivity towards ethylene was 93% by Ni3Mo/Al2O3 and the only CH4 was observed as byproduct. In comparison with the monometallic Ni and Mo catalyst, the Ni3Mo/Al2O3 catalyst displayed 2 and 10 times higher for ethane conversion respectively with > 90% of ethylene selectivity as shown in Fig. 3(b). The Ni/Mo ratios in the Ni-Mo catalyst exhibited significant effects on the catalytic performance of ethane dehydrogenation (Fig. 3(c)). Keeping the content of Ni-Mo unchanged (1.5 wt%) in the catalysts, a higher ratio of Ni/Mo (Ni/Mo = 4) afforded a good selectivity for ethylene of 95% but low ethane conversion of 4.5%. The decrease of the Ni/Mo to 3 led to an obvious improvement in the conversion and selectivity, endowing the ethane conversion of 11% and selectivity of 93%. Further decrease of the Ni/Mo ratios to 1:1 and 1:3 led to decrement of the conversions to 3.2% and 2.1%, respectively with remained selectivity of 94%. The highest efficiency for ethane dehydrogenation can be achieved in Ni3Mo/Al2O3 catalyst, and thus the optimized Ni/Mo ratio in Ni-Mo/Al2O3 should be around 3. Fig. 3(d) showed the catalytic properties of the Ni3Mo/Al2O3 after calcinating at 500, 600, 700, and 800 °C respectively in air for 3 h. For the samples annealed at 500 and 600 °C, the ethane conversions were slightly increased to 13%, but the ethylene selectivity was lower than 90%. When the calcination temperature increased to 700 °C, the ethane conversion was decayed to 11% but the ethylene selectivity was increased to 93%. However, further increased the calcination temperature to 800 °C, the conversion was sharply decreased to 2%, suggesting the strong interaction of the metal with support was unbenefited for the ethane conversion. These results demonstrated that under high temperature calcinating treatment, the interaction of the metal and support increased, affecting the catalytic performance strongly. After screening calcination temperatures and Ni/Mo loadings (Fig. S9(a)), the Ni3Mo/Al2O3 catalyst which was calcined under 700 °C with Ni/Mo loading of 1.5% displayed the best catalytic performance on ethane dehydrogenation. Other parameters such as weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) of ethane, reaction temperature and supports difference were further studied on ethane conversion and ethylene selectivity. The initial performance of Ni3Mo/Al2O3 for catalytic dehydrogenation of ethane at different WHSV was shown in Fig. 3(e). The ethylene selectivity increased with the increase of WHSV from 0.201 to 1.339 h–1 while ethane conversion also increased but then sharply decreased when WHSV reached to 1.339 h–1. These results indicated that properly increasing the WHSV of ethane could promote the desorption of ethylene products and recover of the active sites, thereby improving the ethane conversion and ethylene selectivity. Clearly, highest catalytic yield was achieved when WHSV was 0.804 h–1. As shown in Fig. S9(b), the initial conversion and selectivity for the Ni3Mo/Al2O3 catalyst increased with the increase of the reaction temperature, indicating that high temperature was not only beneficial to the conversion increase, but also to the ethylene desorption. To investigate the effect of different supports on the performance of the Ni3Mo catalysts, the catalytic activity was tested under the same reaction conditions on EDH over SiO2, USY and NaY. Fig. 3(f) displayed the conversion and selectivity against supports where maximum ethane conversion was obtained using NaY molecular but poorest selectivity was observed. Ni3Mo/SiO2 and Ni3Mo/USY displayed similar ethane conversion where 90% ethylene selectivity was obtained by Ni3Mo/USY. Compared with other supports, Al2O3 was the most suitable carrier for EDH with the highest ethane conversion and ethylene selectivity. The long-term durability of Ni/Al2O3, Mo/Al2O3, Ni3Mo/Al2O3 Pt/Al2O3 and PtSn/Al2O3 catalysts were tested under identical conditions (Fig. 4(a) and Fig. S10(a)). The Pt/Al2O3 with 0.79 wt% (Table S3) loading of Pt was prepared and exhibited 6.0% conversion of ethane, but the conversion was rapidly decayed to 1.0% after 1 h and maintained at this low conversion even after 12 h. The catalytic activity and stability of PtSn/Al2O3 were significantly better than Pt/Al2O3, but the ethane conversion was only 6.38%. In addition, the Ni/Al2O3 catalysts exhibited ethane conversion of 5.2% and ethylene selectivity of 95% at the beginning of the reaction (Fig. S10(a)). However, the catalytic activities were rapidly decreased with the reaction time and only 2.4% of the ethane conversion observed after 12 h. Meanwhile, the Mo/Al2O3 showed low activity on EDH reaction with only ethane conversion of 1% and ethylene selectivity of 90% (Fig. S10(a)). Interestingly, the Ni3Mo/Al2O3 displayed better durability on EDH where the ethane conversion slightly decreased to 7.4% with constant selectivity of ~92% after 12 h (Fig. 4(a)), indicating the synergistic effect of Ni and Mo on the improvement of catalytic performance. These data confirmed the superior durability of Ni3Mo/Al2O3 catalyst in the EDH that remarkably outperformed the supported Pt- catalysts as well as the supported Mo and Ni catalysts. The Raman spectrum of the catalyst after the reaction (Fig. S11) showed that the Ni3Mo/Al2O3 has a higher proportion of amorphous carbon than other catalysts. We also evaluated the catalytic performance of Ni3Mo/Al2O3 under H2-free conditions (Fig. S10(b)). When the feed was 20% C2H6/Ar, the catalyst deactivated quickly, but the catalytic performance was well maintained when pure ethane was fed, demonstrating the excellent industrial application potential of this catalyst. The recyclability of the Ni3Mo/Al2O3 catalyst was studied by an oxidative regeneration step in flowing air at 500 °C for 2 h. Notably, the ethane conversion and ethylene selectivity over Ni3Mo/Al2O3 catalyst exhibited no obvious decrease after 3 successive regeneration cycles (Fig. 4(b)), indicating the excellent stability of the Ni3Mo alloyed NPs for EDH. 3.3 Identification of intermediates in ethane dehydrogenation reaction The surface species of Ni3Mo/Al2O3 in ethane dehydrogenation were detected by in situ FTIR where 30% ethane was introduced into the pretreated Ni3Mo/Al2O3 surface at 550 °C. At the beginning of ethane introduction, there was no obvious peak were observed. Notably, after prolonging the reaction time, the peaks at 1508 and 1845 cm–1 were appeared which were attributed to the metal hydrogen species (M-H*) and metal ethyl species (M-C2H5*) [ 65 ]. Clearly, the concentration of M-H* and M-C2H5* increased with the time (Fig. 4(c)). Subsequently, the Ni3Mo/Al2O3 surface was purged with Ar, and the infrared peaks at these two positions disappeared (Fig. 4(d)), indicating in situ transformation of M-H* and M-C2H5* to H2 and ethylene. Simultaneously, due to the formation of the ethylene was easily occurred under this condition, a characteristic peak of metal ethylene species (M-C2H4*) was observed throughout the entire process (Figs. 4(c) and (d)) [ 65–67 ]. 3.4 Synergistic effect in Ni3Mo/Al2O3 In order to better understand the superior EDH performance of the Ni3Mo/Al2O3 catalyst, the activation energy (E a) for C2H6 conversion and C2H6-TPSR experiments were performed over Ni/Al2O3, Mo/Al2O3 and Ni3Mo/Al2O3 catalysts under the same reaction conditions. According to the Madon-Boudart criterion, if the reaction is in the catalytic reaction kinetic region, the conversion of the reaction should be constant when the feed flow rate and catalyst mass changed proportionally, and changing the particle size of the catalyst should not influence the conversion of the reaction. At this time, the intrinsic activity should be independent of the flow rate of reactants at a given WHSV [ 68 ]. We determined that the ethane conversion became a constant when WHSV = 13.66 h–1 and ethane flow rate F ≥ 34 mL min–1 was used, indicating the kinetic experiment was not influenced by interphase diffusion (Fig. 5(a) ). Under this condition, the influence of intra-particle diffusion was eliminated by adjusting the size of the catalyst particles (Fig. 5(b)). Ethane Dehydrogenation is a reversible reaction, so the ethylene generation rate (r C2H4) measured in the experiment was equal to the rate (C2H6) of Ethane Dehydrogenation to ethylene minused the rate (C2H4) of ethylene consumption in ethylene hydrogenation (r C2H4 = C2H6 – C2H4) [ 69,70 ]. Under the high WHSV reaction conditions optimized by Madon-Boudart test, the ethane conversion was between 2.10% and 4.16%, but its equilibrium conversion ranged from 14.46 to 26.10% (Table 1 ). Therefore, although the conversion rate of ethane was low, it could not be guaranteed to be far away from the thermodynamic equilibrium. We used the fraction approach to thermodynamic equilibrium (Frac. Appr. to Equil.) to shown how it approached thermodynamic equilibrium. The Frac. Appr. to Equil. was equal to the reaction quotient (Q) divided by the equilibrium constant (K). If it was less than 10%, it could be considered that the reaction was far away from equilibrium, and the measured rate was not influenced by reversibility. Therefore, the ethylene hydrogenation could be ignored, and the measured ethylene formation rate could be used as the true positive rate of ethane dehydrogenation [ 72 ]. The activation energy obtained by the Arrhenius plot were shown in Fig. 5(c), the Ni3Mo/Al2O3 exhibited a lower E a (111 kJ mol−1) than those of Ni/Al2O3 (157 kJ mol−1) and Mo/Al2O3 (171 kJ mol−1). The lower E a clarified the improved intrinsic activity of the Ni3Mo/Al2O3 compared to that of the monometallic catalyst [ 73 ], which might ascribe to the easier activation of C2H6 at Ni3Mo alloy sites. The C2H6-TPSR results (Figs. 5(d)–(f)) showed that the temperature at which C2H4 begins to be formed was lower on Ni3Mo/Al2O3 (~450 °C) than that on Ni/Al2O3 (~477 °C) and that on Mo/Al2O3 (~520 °C). Correspondingly, H2 signal and C2H6 signal were gradually increased and declined, respectively suggesting that Ni3Mo/Al2O3 displayed a greater ability to activate C2H6. 3.5 DFT calculations DFT calculations were employed to elucidate the nature of high activity of ethane dehydrogenation on Ni3Mo [ 74 ]. First, we compared the activity of ethane decomposition on close-packed (111) surface of fcc Ni, (110) surface of bcc Mo and (100) surface of Ni3Mo in Pmmn space group. Ethane exhibited weak interaction with the Ni(111) and Mo(110) surfaces where the C–C bond was nearly parallel to the surface (Figs. 6(a) and (b) ) and the adsorption energies was −0.03 and −0.04 eV, respectively. Interestingly, when ethane was adsorbed at the bridge site composed by Ni and Mo on Ni3Mo(100) surfaces, the adsorption energy was increased to −0.15 eV (Fig. 6(c)) where ethane molecule was rotated by an angle of 35o and one carbon in ethane was close to Mo and the Mo−C distance was 2.847 Å, which was shorter than Ni−C distance (3.893 Å) on Ni(111) and Mo-C distance (3.967 Å) on Mo(110) (Figs. 6(d)−(f)), indicating the ethane adsorption was enhanced over Ni3Mo surface. Importantly, C−H bond of CH3 group close to Ni3Mo(100), was 1.122Å which was longer than 1.105 Å on Ni(111) and 1.106 Å on Mo(110), indicating the easier activation of C−H bond over Ni3Mo(100) surface, thereby clarifying the intrinsic promoted activity of for ethane dehydrogenation by Ni3Mo(100). The different adsorption geometries were caused by the larger electronegativity of Ni than Mo, which led to the electron transport from Mo to Ni, and the Bader charge for Mo and Ni atoms were 0.49 and −0.20 on Ni3Mo(001). Electron losing made Mo atom eager to appeal electron from methyl in adsorbed ethane while electron enrichment on Ni resulted in the repulsion between Ni and another methyl in ethane. Such different electronic effects made the rotation of ethane. In addition, the charge density difference indicated that more electrons were accumulated at the zone between ethane and Ni3Mo(100) than that for Ni(111) and Mo(110) surfaces (Figs. 6(g)−(i)), indicating the pre-activation of ethane on Ni3Mo(100) was more beneficial. We further calculated the stepwise dehydrogenation mechanisms of ethane on the Ni(111), Mo(110) and Ni3Mo(100) surfaces (Fig. 7 and Fig. S12). Taking the C2H6/H2 ratio (2.5:1) in raw and binding strengths (−0.15 and −1.13 eV, Fig. S13) on Ni3Mo(100) of ethane and hydrogen into consideration, the geometries with co-adsorbed C2H6 and H2 on Ni(111), Mo(110) and Ni3Mo(100) were selected as the starting states. Thermodynamically, first hydrogen abstraction of ethane, C2H6 → C2H5 + H, was endothermic by 0.21 eV on Ni(111) surface but exothermic by 0.59 and 0.39 eV on Mo(110) and Ni3Mo(100) surfaces as shown in Fig. 7. Besides, the subsequent elementary reactions to ethylene and acetylene on Ni(111), Mo(110) and Ni3Mo(100) surfaces were all exergonic, which led to strong exothermic properties apparently of ethane dehydrogenation referring to adsorbed ethane. Kinetically, first C–H bond activation in ethane (C2H6 → C2H5 + H) exhibited higher energy barrier than the energy barriers for the step from ethyl to ethylene and two steps for ethylene deep dehydrogenation on Ni(111) (0.78 vs. 0.09, 0.46, 0.28 eV, Fig. 7(a)), Mo(110) (0.83 vs. 0.19, 0.42, 0.03 eV, Fig. 7(b)) and Ni3Mo(100) (0.57 vs. 0.16, 0.46, 0.04 eV, Fig. 7(c)) surfaces, indicating the first C-H bond scission was the rate-determining step on these three metallic surfaces. Since the transition state of C2H6 → C2H5 + H, which occupied the highest energy level among these three potential energy surfaces, the apparent barrier was determined with respect to state with co-adsorbed ethane and hydrogen. Clearly, Ni3Mo(100) was more active and showed lower apparent barrier (0.57 eV) than the pure Ni (111) (0.78 eV) and Mo(110) (0.83 eV) as shown in Fig. 7(d), and the sequence was in consist with the experimental activity on ethane dehydrogenation, Ni3Mo > Ni > Mo. Considering the change of reaction energy (0.21, −0.59, −0.39 eV) and energy barrier (0.78, 0.83, 0.57 eV) for converting ethane to ethyl on Ni(111), Mo(110) and Ni3Mo(100) surface, introducing Mo into Ni matrix shifted the thermodynamic property from endothermic to exothermic, and improved the activity of ethane conversion kinetically. As for the ethylene selectivity, it was clear that desorption energy of ethylene over Ni and Ni3Mo was similar but much lower than that over Mo as shown in Fig. 7(e), indicating the formation of Ni3Mo improved the ethylene selectivity significantly compared with the Mo catalyst. 4 Conclusions We designed and prepared a Ni based alloy NPs on Al2O3 and the composition of the alloys was crucial to achieve outperform catalytic activity for ethane dehydrogenation. Nanoparticulate Ni-Mo with the Ni/Mo ratio of 3 outperformed those of Ni alloyed catalyst with other metals and ratios. This promotion was accomplished not only by finely controlling the alloy composition but also by changing the adsorption configuration from parallel on Ni/Mo to incline on Ni3Mo. Moreover, Ni3Mo/Al2O3 exhibited much lower activation energy over (111 kJ mol–1) than Ni (157 kJ mol–1) and Mo (171 kJ mol–1). Thus, the results obtained in this study provide a new insight for the identification of active sites in alkane dehydrogenation and a feasible direction for the improvement of alkane dehydrogenation catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Modifying the electronic density of states and the synergistic effect of the active centers by introducing a second metal present an efficient strategy to tune physi/chemi-sorption, probably lead to improving catalytic performances. Herein, bimetallic Ni3Mo/Al2O3 catalyst was demonstrated and exhibited over 5 times more active than Pt/Al2O3 toward the ethane dehydrogenation (EDH) as well as 2–10 times activity enhancement compared with their monometallic Ni and Mo counterparts and other Ni-based bimetallic nanoparticles. Kinetic studies revealed that the activation energy over Ni3Mo/Al2O3 (111 kJ mol–1) was much lower than that of Ni (157 kJ mol–1) and Mo (171 kJ·mol–1). DFT calculations showed ethane was adsorbed on the Ni or Mo surface in a more parallel configuration, whereas over Ni3Mo it adopted an inclined configuration. This change promoted ethane adsorption and pre-activation of the C–H bond, thereby benefiting the ethane dehydrogenation process on the Ni3Mo surface.
